prior_works.title: NeRF: Representing Scenes as Neural Radiance Fields for View Synthesis
prior_works.authors: Ben Mildenhall, Pratul P. Srinivasan, Matthew Tancik, Jonathan T. Barron, Ravi Ramamoorthi, Ren Ng
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MSTH adopts NeRF’s volumetric rendering setup and supervision signals, but replaces NeRF’s MLP representation with a masked mix of 3D and 4D hash encodings to better handle dynamic scenes efficiently.

prior_works.title: Instant Neural Graphics Primitives with a Multiresolution Hash Encoding
prior_works.authors: Thomas Müller, Alex Evans, Christoph Schied, Alexander Keller
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MSTH directly builds on Instant-NGP’s hash grids, extending them from 3D to a coupled 3D/4D design and introducing a learnable mask to reduce redundant queries and mitigate hash collisions in largely static regions.

prior_works.title: Neural Sparse Voxel Fields (NSVF)
prior_works.authors: Lingjie Liu, Jiatao Gu, Kyaw Zaw Lin, Tat-Seng Chua, Christian Theobalt
prior_works.role: Explicit sparse grid acceleration and occupancy/masking
prior_works.relationship_sentence: NSVF’s use of sparse voxel structures to avoid unnecessary sampling motivates MSTH’s masking of static areas to skip redundant updates and queries, improving efficiency in space-time.

prior_works.title: NeRF in the Wild: Neural Radiance Fields for Unconstrained Photo Collections
prior_works.authors: Ricardo Martin-Brualla, Noha Radwan, Mehdi S. M. Sajjadi, Jonathan T. Barron, Alexey Dosovitskiy, Daniel Duckworth
prior_works.role: Uncertainty and transient components for masking
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MSTH’s uncertainty-guided objective for its learnable mask echoes NeRF-W’s strategy of modeling uncertainty/transient phenomena to down-weight unreliable or non-static content.

prior_works.title: Nerfies: Deformable Neural Radiance Fields
prior_works.authors: Keunhong Park, Utkarsh Sinha, Jonathan T. Barron, Sofien Bouaziz, Dan B. Goldman, Steven M. Seitz, Ricardo Martin-Brualla
prior_works.role: Dynamic scene modeling via deformation fields
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By showing the challenges of deformation-based dynamic modeling, Nerfies motivates MSTH’s deformation-free alternative that uses an explicit 4D hash branch plus a static 3D branch mediated by a mask.

prior_works.title: K-Planes: Explicit Radiance Fields in Space, Time, and Appearance
prior_works.relationship_sentence: K-Planes demonstrates the efficiency of explicit space-time parameterizations; MSTH similarly embraces explicit 4D encoding but couples it with a 3D static encoding and a gating mask to minimize redundancy and storage.

prior_works.title: Plenoxels: Radiance Fields without Neural Networks
prior_works.authors: Alex Yu, Ruilong Li, Matthew Tancik, Hao Li, Ren Ng, Angjoo Kanazawa
prior_works.role: Fast optimization of explicit scene parameters
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Plenoxels’ success with optimizing explicit coefficients motivates MSTH’s hash-table parameterization and contributes to its rapid convergence compared to heavy per-time-step networks.

synthesis_narrative: MSTH’s core idea—mixing 3D and 4D hash encodings through a learnable, uncertainty-guided mask to efficiently reconstruct dynamic scenes—arises from converging threads in neural rendering. NeRF establishes the volumetric rendering backbone, while Instant-NGP provides the pivotal multi-resolution hash encoding that MSTH directly extends to a coupled 3D/4D setting. Recognizing that many dynamic videos contain largely static content, NSVF’s sparse voxel philosophy inspires masking to avoid unnecessary space-time queries and updates, thereby cutting collisions and storage. Handling real-world variability, NeRF in the Wild introduces uncertainty and transient modeling; MSTH adapts this principle by using an uncertainty-guided objective to steer its mask toward spatial-temporal importance, enabling it to route points to either the static 3D or dynamic 4D branch. Dynamic NeRF works like Nerfies underscore both the need to capture non-rigid motion and the optimization burdens of deformation-field approaches; MSTH proposes a deformation-free alternative via explicit 4D encoding. Contemporary explicit dynamic representations such as K-Planes validate the efficiency of explicit space-time parameterizations; MSTH’s hybrid 3D/4D design further trims redundancy in predominantly static regions. Finally, Plenoxels’ success with optimizing explicit scene parameters informs MSTH’s choice of hash-table parameters that train quickly and scale. Together, these works shape MSTH’s masked space-time hashing, achieving lower collisions, reduced storage, and faster convergence for dynamic scene reconstruction.
